clinical_study.brief_title: Virtual-reality and Emotion Regulation in Violence-Exposed Youth
clinical_study.official_title: Virtual-reality and Emotion Regulation in Violence-Exposed Youth

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this proposal is to determine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a novel virtual-reality-based biofeedback (VR-B) treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD is driven in part by difficulty self-regulating emotional and physical arousal. Biofeedback, which involves the provision of real-time information about physiology, is a well-studied approach to enhancing self-regulatory ability, with potential promise for PTSD. In children (as well as adults), biofeedback may be ideally facilitated through video game environments, which offer engaging, immersive, yet dynamic environments that can be changed in real-time. Video games are enormously popular with youth, and may represent an important avenue for treatment in pediatric populations. The current proposal aims to evaluate a novel virtual-reality-based video game treatment for dysregulation in PTSD. This pilot study will: 1) evaluate the feasibility of applying a VR-B treatment for youth with PTSD, 2) identify potential changes in physiological signaling (e.g., heart rate) across treatment sessions, 3) identify potential changes in self-regulatory ability or symptom severity across treatment sessions.

detailed_description.textblock:
Post-traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is common in adolescence and causes significant suffering and burden throughout the lifespan. The incidence of PTSD rises markedly in adolescence, reaching a lifetime prevalence of 5% by age 18 and up to 40% in cases of sexual abuse and assault. In addition to psychological suffering, PTSD is associated with lower academic achievement and increased incidence of depression, suicide attempts, and substance abuse into adulthood. Childhood trauma and PTSD also impose tremendous societal costs in terms of health care utilization and financial outlay. For example, the sequelae of childhood maltreatment, including PTSD, cost the United States an estimated $500 billion annually. These sobering statistics highlight the urgent need to uncover novel, evidence-based treatments to improve the well-being of afflicted youth. Unfortunately, current pharmacological approaches to youth PTSD show only minimal efficacy. Psychotherapy offers modest benefits, yet only for some, and only temporarily.
Advances may come from multidisciplinary efforts to evaluate and adapt current treatments. Many mental illnesses, including PTSD, are driven in part by difficulty self-regulating emotional and physical arousal. Biofeedback is an evidence-based mental health treatment involving provision of real-time information about physiological arousal. Individuals learn to recognize the bodily sensations of high arousal and use acquired skills or conditioned behavior to control that arousal. Yet this approach has historically been difficult for youth, as it requires sustained attention and engagement to the biofeedback signals. The current proposal aims to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a novel virtual-reality-based video game biofeedback system.
Video games are an ideal treatment vehicle for adolescents - nearly 97% of whom play video games on a regular basis - as well as an established avenue for training cognitive processes, such as effortful autonomic regulation. Davidson and colleagues recently demonstrated that a mobile game teaching focused attention on breathing enhanced functional connectivity in prefrontal regulatory circuits among adolescents. Biofeedback-based breath awareness is an efficacious technique for augmenting effortful autonomic regulation. Regularized guided breathing treatment decreases autonomic reactivity to stress among adults with PTSD. Notably, common approaches to biofeedback with heart rate or respiration make use of textual or abstract graphical feedback (e.g., sine waves, breaths per minute). Virtual reality allows biofeedback to be embedded in the characteristics of the environment itself, thereby sustaining attention and engagement, with proven benefits over traditional implementations. Indeed, VR-based applications are now widely used to great benefit for a variety of psychiatric disorders. This will be the first study to integrate these concepts - virtual reality and biofeedback - for the targeted treatment of adolescent PTSD and suicidal ideation.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Individual differences in efficacy/tolerability among 20 youth

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Trauma Symptoms Checklist for Children - Short Form (TSCC-SF) Score
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and up to 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6)
primary_outcome.description: The TSCC-SF is a 12-item child report survey that measures the frequency (severity) of post-traumatic stress symptoms in children. Respondents characterize the frequency with which they experience each symptom on a scale of 0 = Never to 3 = Almost All of the Time, with a possible total score range of 0 - 36, where higher scores indicate greater symptom severity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The CBCL is a 112-item parent-report survey measuring the occurrence of common behavioral and emotional problems in children. Respondents report each statement's accuracy in describing their child over the past six months using a Likert scale: 0 = Not True, 1 = Somewhat or Sometimes True, and 2 = Very True or Often True, with a possible total score range of 0 - 224, with higher scores indicative of a greater number of behavioral and emotional problems.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The YSR is a 112-item child-report survey measuring the occurrence of common behavioral and emotional problems in children. Respondents report each statement's accuracy in describing themselves over the past six months using a Likert scale: 0 = Not True, 1 = Somewhat or Sometimes True, and 2 = Very True or Often True, with a possible total score range of 0 - 224, with higher scores indicative of a greater number of behavioral and emotional problems.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The CTQ is a 28-item child-report survey measuring the types and frequency of common traumatic experiences. Respondents report the frequency with which a given event occurred in their lifetime on a five point Likert scale: 0 = Never True to 4 = Very Often True, with a possible total score range of 0 - 112. Higher scores indicate a greater frequency/variety of traumatic experiences.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Difficulty in Emotion Regulation Scale (DERS)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The DERS is a 36-item child-report survey measuring difficulties with emotion regulation. Respondents report the degree to which the given statement applied to them on a five point Likert scale: 1 = Almost Never to 5 = Always, with a possible total score range of 36 - 180. Higher scores indicate greater difficulties with emotion regulation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ) - Child Report
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The MFQ - Child Report is a 33-item child-report survey measuring symptoms of childhood-onset depression. Respondents report the degree to which each statement describes them on a three point Likert scale: 0 = Not True, 1 = Sometimes, 2 = True, with a possible total score range of 0 - 66. Higher scores indicate greater severity of depression symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ) - Parent Report
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The MFQ - Parent Report is a 33-item parent-report survey measuring symptoms of childhood-onset depression. Respondents report the degree to which each statement describes their child on a three point Likert scale: 0 = Not True, 1 = Sometimes, 2 = True, with a possible total score range of 0 - 66. Higher scores indicate greater severity of depression symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (MAIA) - Child Report
secondary_outcome.description: The MAIA - Child Report is a 32-item child-report survey measuring awareness of physiological changes in the body due to emotions/other states and attitudes towards these sensations. Respondents report how often they act in a manner consistent with each statement on a six point Likert scale: 0 = Never to 5 = Always, with a total possible score range of 0 - 160. Higher scores indicate more adaptive awareness of emotion-related bodily sensations.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (MAIA) - Parent Report
secondary_outcome.description: The MAIA - Parent Report is a 32-item parent-report survey measuring their child's awareness of physiological changes in the body due to emotions/other states and attitudes towards these sensations. Respondents report how often their child acts in a manner consistent with each statement on a six point Likert scale: 0 = Never to 5 = Always, with a total possible score range of 0 - 160. Higher scores indicate more adaptive awareness of emotion-related bodily sensations in the child.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Resiliency Scale for Children and Adolescents (RSCA)
secondary_outcome.description: The RSCA is a 64-item child-report survey measuring resiliency and emotional reactivity to negative life events. Respondents select the degree to which each statement reflects themselves along a five point Likert scale: 0 = Never to 4 = Almost Always, with a possible total score range of 0 - 256. Higher scores indicate greater resiliency/less emotional reactivity to negative events.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Screen for Child Anxiety Related Emotional Disorders (SCARED) - Child Report
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The SCARED - Child Report is a 40-item child-report survey measuring the severity of anxiety symptoms over the past three months. Respondents select the veracity of each statement on a three point Likert scale: 0 = Not True or Hardly Ever True, 1 = Somewhat True of Sometimes True, 2 = Very True or Often True, with a possible total score range of 0 - 80. Higher scores indicate greater severity of anxiety symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Screen for Child Anxiety Related Emotional Disorders (SCARED) - Parent Report
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The SCARED - Parent Report is a 40-item parent-report survey measuring the severity of their child's anxiety symptoms over the past three months. Respondents select the veracity of each statement in relation to their child on a three point Likert scale: 0 = Not True or Hardly Ever True, 1 = Somewhat True of Sometimes True, 2 = Very True or Often True, with a possible total score range of 0 - 80. Higher scores indicate greater severity of anxiety symptoms in the child.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in UCLA PTSD-Reaction Index (UCLA PTSD-RI) - Child Report
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The UCLA PTSD-RI - Child Report is a 27-item child-report survey measuring the severity of post-traumatic stress symptoms over the past month. Respondents select the frequency with which they experienced each symptom over the past month on a five point Likert scale: 0 = None/Never to 4 = Most/Almost Every Day, with a possible total score range of 0 - 108. Higher scores indicate greater severity of post-traumatic stress symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in UCLA PTSD-Reaction Index (UCLA PTSD-RI) - Parent Report
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 6 weeks (2-week follow-up after study day 6).
secondary_outcome.description: The UCLA PTSD-RI - Parent Report is a 27-item parent-report survey measuring the severity of post-traumatic stress symptoms in the child over the past month. Respondents select the frequency with which their child experienced each symptom over the past month on a five point Likert scale: 0 = None/Never to 4 = Most/Almost Every Day, with a possible total score range of 0 - 108. Higher scores indicate greater severity of post-traumatic stress symptoms in the child.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change in Virtual-Reality Biofeedback Engagement Survey (VR-B)
secondary_outcome.description: The VR-B is a 10-item child-report survey measuring engagement with the virtual-reality biofeedback intervention. Respondents select the degree to which they agree with each statement along a Likert scale: 1 = Strongly Disagree to 7 = Strongly Agree, with a possible total score range of 10 - 70. Higher scores indicate greater engagement with the VR-B intervention.

arm_group.description: Youth will be asked to experience an immersive virtual-reality simulation. Youth will wear a lightweight, ultra-high-resolution, wireless, head-mounted VR display (HTC Vive Pro Eye; HTC Corp., Taiwan). Each session will proceed through a series of three stages. First, participants will begin with a 5-min. acclimation period inside a demo VR environment. Second, baseline levels of physiological arousal will be captured over a 5 min. resting period where participants will be asked to sit quietly in a serene virtual environment. Physiological data will be collected using disposable gel-pad electrodes placed on the fingers (galvanic skin response) and torso (electrocardiography). Third, youth will progress through the DEEP VR experience for 15 minutes (see Behavioral Task), an underwater navigation video game wherein regularized, diaphragmatic breathing facilitates movement.

intervention.description: DEEP VR is a virtual reality experience (i.e., video game using a head-mounted display) wherein participants ('players') traverse through a serene underwater adventure for approximately 15 min. Movement through the environment is facilitates through the cued use of regularized, diaphragmatic breathing, captured through a respiratory belt.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. 10 to 16 years of age at enrollment
2. Accompanied by an eligible caregiver
3. Able to provide assent/consent in English
4. Visual acuity adequate to read text on a computer monitor
5. Must have a history of abuse, defined here as exposure to physical or sexual abuse.
6. Must meet criteria necessary to support a diagnosis of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Youth may have comorbid disorders other than those listed in the exclusion criteria.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Ongoing trauma
2. Active substance use disorder
3. Imminent suicidality
4. Obsessive-compulsive disorder
5. Bipolar/psychotic disorder
6. Neurodevelopmental disorders such as Autism Spectrum Disorder or Intellectual Disability
7. Unstable medical condition, such as newly diagnosed Type I diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis
8. Neurological disorder(s) such as seizures, epilepsy, or brain tumors
9. Traumatic brain injury with ongoing symptoms, including headache, visual disturbances, and/or impairments in concentration
10. No past or present diagnosis of PTSD
11. Report of previous discomfort with immersive experiences, including virtual reality, 3D films, or similar media.

patient_data.ipd_description: Information to be shared may include questionnaire responses, physiological recordings, or game play data. These data will be coded with the unique subject ID, and will not include any linking protected health information or other identifiable information. Data will be shared via encrypted, password protected cloud storage (Box.com).
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Information will only be shared with the following individuals with knowledge of the methodology and analyses in this intervention: Dr. Isabele Granic, University of Toronto Joanneke Weerdmeester, Radboud University Owen L. Harris, Explore DEEP Inc.
